questions.question: New school registration or monitoring update?

tooltip.text: Entry of school data in RTMIS (first time) or update of monitoring data (existing school)

questions.question: Geolocation of school
School respondent: role/position

tooltip.text: List of school positions/roles

questions.question: Total number of students enrolled in school

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: what is the total number of students currently enrolled in this school?

questions.question: Number of boys (male students) enrolled in school

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: what is the total number of boys currently enrolled in this school?

questions.question: Number of girls (female students) enrolled in school

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: what is the total number of girls currently enrolled in this school?

questions.question: Number of students with disability enrolled in school

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: what is the total number of students with disability currently enrolled in this school?

question_groups.description: This question contains a list of possible school locations, starting with the government area or district, down to the community.

questions.question: What is the location of the school?

tooltip.text: This question contains a list of possible school locations, starting with the government area or district, down to the community.

questions.question: Main source of drinking water

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE & INTERVIEW: what is the main source of drinking water for the school?
Main source: if there is more than one water source, select the one used most frequently for drinking water

questions.question: Number of water points

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: how many drinking water points (e.g. taps) are available to students at the school?
Number of water points: count the total number of drinking water points available to students at the school

questions.question: Drinking water availability: current

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE & INTERVIEW: is drinking water from the main water source currently available at the school?
Currently available: drinking water is available at the time of the interview, either from the main source directly or stored water originally from the main source

questions.question: Drinking water availability: throughout school year

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE & INTERVIEW: is drinking water typically available throughout the school year?
Throughout the school year: drinking water is available throughout the school year, when the students are at school

options.name: No (unavailable for more than 30 days in total)
Mostly (unavailable for up to 30 days in total)

questions.question: Drinking water treatment

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE & INTERVIEW: what treatment method is used ot make the water from the main source safe to drink?
SODIS: solar disinfection (plastic bottles placed in sun for a number of hours)

questions.question: Drinking water accessibility: students with limited mobility or vision

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is drinking water accessible to those with limited mobility or vision?
Accessible: drinking water can be accessed (directly from the source or from a storage container) via a clear path without stairs or steps that is free of obstruction and has age-appropriate handrails; the tap can be reached from a seated position; and the water source/dispsenser can be opened and closed with minimal effort with one closed fist or foot

questions.question: Drinking water accessibility: smallest students

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is drinking water accessible to the smallest children at the school?
Accessible: drinking water can be reached (directly from the source or from a storage container) and the water source/dispenser can be easily opened and closed by the smallest children

questions.question: School toilet interface type

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: main type of toilet interface
Toilet interface: part of the toilet through which the excreta pass into the containment system
Examples: 1. Drophole, 2. Pour-flush pan, 3. SATO pan.

options.name: Flush or pour-flush pan with water seal

questions.question: School toilet containment or collection system

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: main type of excreta containment or collection system
Main type: the most common type of student toilet should be selected
Containment system: pit or tank (or other) that contains and stores excreta
Collection system: connection through which excreta and wastewater are collected
Examples: 1. Latrine pit; 2. Septic tank; 3. Sewer connection.
Flush to don't know: household does not know where the toilet flushes to, but no surface outlets or open discharges are visible (in this case, likely to be a buried pit or tank)

options.name: No pit or tank (discharge to open: field, open drain, water body, elsewhere)

questions.question: Durable school toilet slabs

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: durable toilet slabs observed in school toilets?
Durable toilet slab: toilet slab or floor is made from durable materials.
Examples of durable toilet slabs: 1. Concrete toilet slab; 2. Concrete toilet slab covered with ceramic tiles; 3. Structural plastic slab.

options.name: G3 All functional school toilets have durable toilet slabs
G0 All school toilet slabs are NOT durable
G1 Some school toilet slabs are NOT durable

questions.question: Durable school toilet pits

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: durable toilet pits observed in school toilets?
OBSERVE: are there any signs of collapse or damage to the school toilet containment or collection system?
INTERVIEW (where containment not visible): were any materials used to support the sides of the containment system?
INTERVIEW (where containment not visible): does the soil collapse without support?
INTERVIEW (where containment not visible): has the toilet pit collapsed in the last 12 months?
Durable toilet containment (in stable soils): unlined pits may be assessed as durable in areas where other unlined pits are known to be stable and long-lasting.
Durable toilet containment (in UNSTABLE soils): the pit or tank should either be lined with durable materials (e.g. concrete, brickwork, blockwork), or lined with resilient local materials approved by the county public health office for pit linings.

options.name: G0 All toilet pits are NOT durable
G1 Some toilet pits are NOT durable
G3 All functional toilet pits are durable

questions.question: Status of girls only school toilet

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: count the number of girls-only school toilets
OBSERVE: assess whether the girls-only school toilets are functional
Functional: toilet is not broken, toilet hole is not blocked, and water is available for flushing (where required)

options.name: All girls-only school toilets are NON-functional (specify number of non-functional toilets)
Some girls-only school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)
All girls-only school toilets are functional (specify number of functional toilets)

questions.question: Number of girls only non functional toilet

options: All girls-only school toilets are NON-functional (specify number of non-functional toilets)
Some girls-only school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)

questions.question: Number of girls only functional toilet

options: Some girls-only school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)
All girls-only school toilets are functional (specify number of functional toilets)

questions.question: Status of boys only school toilets

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: count the number of boys-only school toilets
OBSERVE: assess whether the boys-only school toilets are functional
Functional: toilet is not broken, toilet hole is not blocked, and water is available for flushing (where required)

options.name: All boys-only school toilets are NON-functional (specify number of non-functional toilets)
Some boys-only school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)
All boys-only school toilets are functional (specify number of functional toilets)

questions.question: Number of boys only non functional toilet

options: All boys-only school toilets are NON-functional (specify number of non-functional toilets)
Some boys-only school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)

questions.question: Number of boys only functional toilets

options: Some boys-only school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)
All boys-only school toilets are functional (specify number of functional toilets)

questions.question: Status of  shared only school toilets

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: count the number of shared school toilets
OBSERVE: assess whether the shared school toilets are functional
Functional: toilet is not broken, toilet hole is not blocked, and water is available for flushing (where required)

options.name: All shared school toilets are NON-functional (specify number of non-functional toilets)
Some shared school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)
All shared school toilets are functional (specify number of functional toilets)

questions.question: Number of functional shared toilet

options: Some shared school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)
All shared school toilets are functional (specify number of functional toilets)

questions.question: Number of non functional shared toilet

options: All shared school toilets are NON-functional (specify number of non-functional toilets)
Some shared school toilets are non-functional (specify number of functional toilets + number of non-functional toilets)

questions.question: Girl student-toilet ratio

tooltip.text:
total number of girls (female students) enrolled in school divided by total number of functional girls-only toilets (segregated)
Functional: toilet is not broken, toilet hole is not blocked, and water is available for flushing (where required)

fn.fnString: function(){ return ( #1706193332941>0 ? (#1706105453740/ #1706193332941) > 25 ? \"More than 25 girl students to each functional girls' toilet\": \"25 or less girl students to each functional girls' toilet\": "No Toilet" ) }

questions.question: Boy student-toilet ratio

tooltip.text:
total number of boys (male students) enrolled in school divided by total number of functional toilets (available to boys-only plus shared toilets available to all students)
Functional: toilet is not broken, toilet hole is not blocked, and water is available for flushing (where required)

fn.fnString: function(){ return ( (#1706096632535 > 0 && #1706195744398 > 0) ? (#1706105426912/ (#1706096632535+ #1706195744398)) > 30 ? \"More than 30 boy students to each functional boys' or shared toilet\": \"30 or less boy students to each functional boys' or shared toilet\":  "No Toilet" ) }

questions.question: Flyproof school toilets

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: are the school toilets flyproof?
Flyproof: toilet design prevents flies from reaching the excreta in the pit (or other containment system).
Examples of flyproof toilets: 1. Pour-flush pit latrine with a functional water-seal pan; 2. VIP latrine with a screened vent pipe; 3. Dry pit latrine with a tight-fitting drophole cover.
Examples of NON-flyproof toilets: 1. Pour-flush latrine with dry water seal (no water); VIP latrine with NO insect screen on vent pipe; 3. Pit latrine with inadequate or missing drophole cover.
Inadequate drophole cover: a cover that is not tight-fitting enough to prevent fly or insect entry into the pit

options.name: All school toilets are NOT flyproof
Some school toilets are NOT flyproof
All functional school toilets are flyproof

questions.question: School toilet privacy

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: do toilet superstructures provide privacy?
Privacy: toilet superstructure has walls and a door that allow use of the toilet without observation by people outside the toilet, with closable doors that lock from the inside and no large openings in the toilet structure.

options.name: All school toilets provide INADEQUATE privacy
Some school toilets provide INADEQUATE privacy
All functional school toilets provide good privacy

questions.question: School toilet availability

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: are school toilets available for use by students?
Available to students: toilet doors are unlocked, or a key is available to students at all times.

options.name: All school toilets UNAVAILABLE to students
Some school toilets UNAVAILABLE to students
All functional school toilets available to students

questions.question: Clean school toilets

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: are the school toilets clean?
Clean: toilets do not have a strong smell; there are not significant numbers of flies or mosquitoes in the toilets; and there are no visible faeces or soiled cleaning materials on the toilet floors, walls, seats (or pans).
Somewhat clean: toilets have some smell and/or some trace of faecal matter or soiled cleansing materials in some of the toilets
NOT clean: there is a strong smell and/or presence of faecal matter or soiled cleansing materials in most toilets

options.name: All functional school toilets are clean

questions.question: No exposed human excreta around school toilets

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: visible human faeces around the school toilets or in the school buildings or compound.

options.name: No visible OD or human excreta

questions.question: Safely managed toilet containment: wastewater contained

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: any evidence of surface outflows from containment systems (for example, visible outflows or leaks; increased vegetation growth around the pit; visible deposits from previous outflows)
Surface outflows from containment: EITHER continuous outflows of faecal sludge or wastewater from overflow pipes, holes or leaks; OR evidence of previous surface outflows (for example, increased vegetation growth around the containment system, or visible sludge deposits from overflows or leaks).

options.name: Evidence of previous surface outflows from containment

questions.question: Safely managed toilet containment: faecal sludge contained

tooltip.text:
<b>INTERVIEW: has the school toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever been emptied?<b></br>
<b>INTERVIEW:<b> has the school toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever filled up?</br>
<b>INTERVIEW: <b>what happened when the school toilet containment (pit, tank or other) last filled up?</br>
<b>INTERVIEW (if the containment system is a lined pit or tank, which has never been emptied): <b>what will happen when the toilet containment is full?</br>
<b>Examples:<b> 1. Never emptied: covered a full toilet pit and dug a new pit; 2. Emptied: emptied the full pit and continued to use it; 3. Connected a second pit and disconnected the full pit. 4. Emptied faecal sludge from septic tank then continued to use.

options.name: Unsafely contained: emptied to open pit or open space
Unsafely contained: emptied to UNLICENSED or UNKNOWN location
Unsafely contained: faecal sludge stored for less than 2 years before emptying and use of stored waste
Safely contained: never emptied, not yet full (no intention to empty)
Safely contained: never emptied, previous pit or tank replaced when full
Safely contained: stored for MORE than 2 years before use of stored waste
Safely contained: emptied to nearby covered pit
Safely contained: emptied by licensed service provider

questions.question: School toilet accessibility: students with limited mobility or vision

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is there at least one functional toilet accessible to those with limited mobility or vision?
Accessible: the toilet can be accessed via a clear path without stairs or steps that is free of obstructions and has age-appropriate handrails; there is enough space inside for a wheelchair user to enter, turn, close the door and park by the toilet; the door is wide enough for a wheelchair (at least 80cm) and opens outward with minimal or no difference in floor height between outside and inside; and the door handle and seat are within reach of students using wheelchairs, crutches or sticks, including a fixed raised pan or movable raised toilet seat to accommodate students who may have difficulty squatting

questions.question: School toilet accessibility: smallest students

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is there at least one functional toilet accessible to the smallest children at the school?
Accessible: the toilet can be used by the smallest children, including (where necessary) a smaller toilet drophole, a lower seat, and a lower door handle.

questions.question: Main location of school handwashing facilities

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: where are school handwashing facilities located?
Location: main location for functional handwashing facilities

options.name: Handwashing facilities in food preparation area
Handwashing facilities in food consumption/dining area

questions.question: Number of school handwashing facilities

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: how many school handwashing facilities are available?
Available: handwashing facility that enables students to wash their hands using running water, such as a basin with tap, water tank with tap, bucket with tap, tippy tap, or other similar device. NB a shared bucket or basin used for dipping hands is NOT considered an effective handwashing facility.

questions.question: Water availability at school handwashing facilities

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is water available at school handwashing facilities?
Water: where soapy water is used for handwashing, non-soapy water must also be available for rinsing hands after washing

options.name: All handwashing facilities have water available
Some handwashing facilities have water available

questions.question: Soap availability at school handwashing facilities

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is soap available at school handwashing facilities?
Soap: solid, liquid or powder soap or detergent

options.name: No soap or other cleanser available
Some handwashing facilities have soap available
All handwashing facilities have soap available

questions.question: School handwashing facility type

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: what is the main type of school handwashing station available?
Permanent handwashing station: facility made from durable materials, with a piped water connection or adequate water storage, and located in a fixed place that is appropriate for handwashing at critical times
Market handwashing station: manufactured handwashing station from durable materials (bought from market or market trader)
Portable basin: open container that can be easily picked up and moved

options.name: Portable basins or other open containers
Market handwashing stations with adequate water storage

questions.question: Hands-free operation of school handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: mechanisms to collect water or trigger water flow
Hands-free operation: handwashing stations are operated by tap, or other hands-free mechanism that minimises contact with the water collection device and the water container

options.name: Hands enter water containers (during collection and use)
Water collected by hand (using ladle, cup, other)
Closed water storage containers with taps

questions.question: Adequate drainage of washing water

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: facilities to collect washing water, and facilities to drain and dispose of the washing water</br>
Collection of washing water: containers to collect dirty washing water (for example, a basin or other container)</br>
Drainage and disposal of washing water: drainage pipes or other facilities to direct the washing water to appropriate disposal points (for example, soakpits or drains)</br>

options.name: No collection or disposal of washing water
Collection of washing water without drainage or disposal
Adequate collection and disposal of washing water

questions.question: Handwashing accessibility: students with limited mobility or vision

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is there at least one handwashing facility accessible to those with limited mobility or vision?
Accessible: the handwashing facility can be accessed via a clear path without stairs or steps that is free of obstructions and has age-appropriate handrails; the tap and soap are reachable from a seated position, and the tap can be operated by feet and/or one closed fist with minimal effort

questions.question: Handwashing accessibility: smallest students

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is there at least one handwashing facility accessible to the smallest children at the school?
Accessible: the smallest children are able to reach the tap and soap, and able to operate the tap on their own with minimal effort

questions.question: Private bathing areas for menstrual hygiene

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: bathing areas adequate for menstrual hygiene
Adequate bathing area: private and girls-only place for washing and menstrual hygiene, with closable doors that lock from the inside, without the possibility of observation by people outside the bathing area

options.name: Private bathing areas for menstrual hygiene

questions.question: Water and soap available in bathing areas for menstrual hygiene

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: water and soap available in bathing areas

options.name: Water and soap are NOT available in bathing areas
Some bathing areas have water and soap available
All bathing areas have both water and soap available

questions.question: Clean bathing areas for menstrual hygiene

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: clean bathing areas available for menstrual hygiene
Clean bathing areas: the places available for washing and menstrual hygiene are clean

options.name: All bathing areas are NOT clean
Some bathing areas are NOT clean
Clean bathing areas for menstrual hygiene

questions.question: Availability of menstrual hygiene materials at the school

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: are menstrual hygiene materials available at the school?
Menstrual hygiene materials and products: disposable and reusable sanitary pads, tampons, and resuable menstrual cups, clean piece of cotton cloth or cotton wool, that are safe and hygienic, and absorb or collect blood during menstrual periods.
Available: menstrual hygiene materials are currently available at the school (via free distribution or for purchase).

options.name: Materials are NOT available or NOT appropriate
Materials are not always available or appropriate

questions.question: Disposal facilities for menstrual hygiene wastes

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: are covered bins available for disposal of menstrual hygiene wastes?

options.name: All bathing areas have covered bins available for menstrual hygiene wastes

questions.question: Disposal system for menstrual hygiene wastes

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: how are menstrual hygiene wastes (in covered bins) collected and disposed?

options.name: Emptied to open pits, open space, open water bodies, open drains
Collected by municpal waste system/licensed service providers

questions.question: Menstrual hygiene education

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: is menstrual hygiene management education available at the school?</br>
